abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Nicaragua and Honduras
            Corazon Transboundary Biosphere Reserve Project for Central
            America were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to global environment outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the development of operational
            tools that take into account the local socio-environmental
            realities is critical to ensuring that operations in
            difficult contexts can be executed in reasonable times.
            Direct sub-project implementation by local governments and
            communities requires previous investments in capacity
            building. Assessment of operational risks under bi-national
            projects must take into account overall political conditions
            and should offer options to surpass barriers and ensure
            continuity of activities. Understanding the indigenous Cosmo
            vision is central to the participation of indigenous peoples
            in projects' execution and to the sustainability of
            interventions. Minimum of 13 percent of the total investment
            is required to cover the costs of adequate monitoring of
            sub-projects in remote areas. Setting explicit targets for
            women participation in implementation of sub-projects in
            indigenous communities ensures their involvement and
            promotes empowerment. The Program Assessment of the Regional
            Environmental Program (PROARCA) and global environment
            facility (GEF) tracking tools can be adapted to better
            capture the socio-environmental conditions of local
            protected areas.
